block.p: Stocks Slide on Worries About Computer Shipments Stocks dropped, pushing the Nasdaq composite index below the 4,000 level as a report that growth in personal computer shipments slowed in the second quarter led to a slide in shares of computer makers.

The Nasdaq composite index fell 112.88 points, or 2.8 percent, to 3,981.57. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 48.44 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,685.12. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index sagged 15.90 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,464.29. [Page C12.]

Merck and Pfizer Post Solid Gains The drugmakers Merck and Pfizer posted strong gains in second-quarter profit. Net income at Merck rose 16 percent, beating Wall Street estimates, while profit from operations at Pfizer gained 21 percent, in line with forecasts. Shares of Merck rose $5.875, to $69.625, while Pfizer closed at $47.5625, up $1.6875, before it announced its results. [C2.]

Roth Urged to Act on Drug Proposal Saying that William V. Roth Jr., the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, appeared to be dragging his feet, Democrats urged him to take action on his proposal to establish prescription drug benefits under Medicare. [A22.]

Demand for King E-Book Falls Short Demand for Stephen King's new electronic book fell far short of his last, an event in March that seemed to foretell a revolution in publishing when 400,000 fans jammed computer servers to download it in the first two days. [C8.]

Sale Speculation Lifts Bear Stearns In the wake of the UBS agreement this month to buy PaineWebber for $12 billion, executives of the remaining independent financial services firms are worrying about being left alone at the dance. Shares of Bear Stearns leaped 7.7 percent on an analyst's report that the firm might be for sale. Market Place. [C11.]

State Farm Is Focus of an Inquiry The National Association of Insurance Commissioners said that it had begun investigating reports that State Farm, the largest auto insurer, improperly denied claims for treatment of injuries in accidents nationwide. [C2.]

BP Amoco Seeks to Revamp Image BP Amoco is undertaking a $7 million rebranding campaign that seeks to reposition the company from an old-economy gas station giant into a progressive, environmentally friendly retailer that goes, in the company's own words, ''beyond petroleum.'' The campaign includes a new green, yellow and white BP sunburst-shaped symbol and a new type of gas station, called BP Connect, where customers will be able to check the forecast for an impending thunderstorm on a small screen at the pump, buy a bottle of wine and some fresh-baked croissants. Advertising. [C6.]

Air Delays Called Underestimated Since 1988, the two agencies that track airline delays have underestimated the amount of time lost by passengers by a total of 247 years, according to a study to be released today. [C7.]
Under a tentative deal to extend its contract with pilots, American Airlines said that it would drop its claim to a $45 million fine for a job action in February 1999. [C7.]
$15 Billion Made in Plane Orders Boeing and Airbus Industrie announced more than $15 billion in orders at the air show in Farnborough, England. [C4.]

H&R Block Settlement Rejected A federal judge has rejected a proposed $25 million settlement in a class-action lawsuit that accuses H & R Block and a lender of being unfair to customers who received tax refund anticipation loans. [C11.]

Russian Company Cleared in Inquiry In a long-running inquiry into embezzlement and money laundering, international auditors have exonerated one of the companies of Boris A. Berezovsky, the top Russian executive and onetime insider who has denounced a Kremlin crackdown on rich businessmen. [C4.]
